1. Use secure communication tools: Choose a communication platform that offers end-to-end encryption or implements industry-standard encryption algorithms. Tools like Signal, Zoom, WhatsApp, and Google Meet offer end-to-end encryption.

2. Use strong passwords and multi-factor authentication: Use strong passwords and enable multi-factor authentication if possible.

3. Manage access to the meeting: Share the meeting links only to the intended participants and avoid sharing it publicly. Also, use a waiting room feature to ensure that the host can verify participants before they join the meeting.

4. Disable the screen sharing feature for attendees: Disable the screen sharing feature for attendees or limit it to specific participants.

5. Record the meeting: Record the meeting for later reference and to identify any security breaches.

6. Use virtual backgrounds: Virtual backgrounds help to hide your surrounding environment, which could include sensitive information.

7. Use updated software and security patches: Keep your software updated with the latest security patches to prevent any potential security breaches.

8. Train participants on security best practices: Educate participants on the best security practices and ways to stay safe during the meetings.
